sist this data. Whatever I have read
> about
> JUnit seems to indicate that=
 the test methods in my test class can be

t framework. Is there any way (a
> pattern) to get around this issue ? Than=
ks much in advance..

Yes, the methods in your test class are not (necessar=
ily) called
in any particular order. This is a feature. Each test method sh=
ould
be unrelated to the others - otherwise it's too hard to eg move
them a=
round for greater expressivity, call only the failing when
when you want to=
 isolate a problem, &co.

There are at least two things you can do:

(a) En=
sure that each test uses its own object (easy) and that it
    runs the pie=
ce of lifecycle you're interested in to
    completion.

(b) Refactor so that this object-state dependency is redu=
ced
    (preferably to zero).

For (b) I'd start by fixing the `connect` pr=
oblem: if nothing
can be done withotu a connection, I'd have a more factory=
-like
object with a `connect` method; calling this delivers a connected
obj=
ect.

For Change/Save, I'd just have the test do the Change and then
the Sa=
ve in the same testXXX() method.

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
It's called *extreme* programming, not *s=
tupid* programming.

To directly answer your question:  You =
can't cast the object because
it was created under a different class loader.  You can only
interact with that class through reflection.  You can't cast it to
types or interfaces -- unless those classes were loaded by a common
class loader -- IE: the system class loader.

I worked around this recentl=
y by loading the TestCase class itself
under the new class loader and calling the current test method on
the new instance, using reflection.  (And setting a flag so that the
new instance knew it was running under the new class loader.)

A bit more =
detail:  The "type" of an instance, its identification,
is the class name *PLUS* the the address of the ClassLoader instance
that loaded it.  That's how web servers keep applications separate
from each other: They create one ClassLoader instance for each
logical application "process" they want to keep separate.

Question:
Since=
 you're already using '.setAccessible(true)' already, why not
use reflection to replace the static singleton instance field?
